topic.title: HPE Helion OpenStack 1.1 and 1.1.1: Installation Prerequisites

p.b: This document describes the installation process for HPE Helion OpenStack 1.1 and HPE Helion OpenStack 1.1.1.

body.p: (If you already have 1.1 installed, you can update Helion OpenStack from 1.1 to 1.1.1 by following the update procedures described in the HPE Helion OpenStack 1.1.1 Update Guide.)
Before you begin the installation process, take a few minutes to read this page for information about:
Make sure the following required tasks are completed before you begin the installation.

section.title: Hardware and software requirements
section.p: Before you start, if you have not done so already, make sure your environment meets the hardware and software requirements. See the HPE Helion OpenStack Support Matrix.

section.title: Preparing the network
section.p: Before installing HPE Helion OpenStack you are responsible for preparing the network for all installations. You must also prepare the network based on the type of hypervisor you are installing, KVM or ESX.
The network is not installed or managed by the cloud. You must install and manage the network and make sure there is a route to the Management network as described in this section.
See the Preparing the Network page.

section.title: Preparing the baremetal systems
section.p: Perform the following tasks on each baremetal system before starting the install:

li.p: Configure the boot order with Network/PXE boot as the first option:

ul.li: For example, to set the boot order for a HPE SL390, from the iLO prompt enter set system1/bootconfig1/bootsource5 bootorder=1.
To unset, enter set system1/bootconfig1/bootsource5 bootorder=5.

with only one network interface enabled for PXE/network boot and any additional interfaces should have PXE/network boot disabled

li.p: Update to the latest firmware recommended by the system vendor for all system components, including the BIOS, BMC firmware, disk controller firmware, drive firmware, network adapter firmware, and so forth.

section.title: Preparing the seed cloud host
section.p: The following tasks need to be performed on the seed cloud host, where the seed VM will be installed. The seed cloud host is alternatively known as the installer system.

ul.li: Create the JSON environment variables file

section.title: Install Ubuntu 14.04 LTS or Debian 8
section.p: The seed cloud host must have Ubuntu 14.04 LTS or Debian 8 installed before performing the HPE Helion OpenStack installation.

section.title: Configure SSH
section.p: On the seed cloud host, the OpenSSH server must be running and the firewall configuration should allow access to the SSH ports.

section.title: Obtain a public key
section.p: On the seed cloud host, the user root must have a public key, for example:
If user root does not have a public key, you can create one using the ssh-keygen -t rsa -N "" command.

section.title: Install Debian or Ubuntu packages
section.p: Before starting the installation, you must first install Debian 8 or Ubuntu 14.04 LTS.
For more information about the Debian or Ubuntu packages that are required for the seed cloud host, see Support Matrix.

section.title: Install and configure NTP
section.p: NTP is a networking protocol for clock synchronization between computer systems.
The HPE Helion OpenStack cloud nodes must be configured as NTP clients and point to the same NTP server.

You can install NTP on the seed cloud host and configure it as an NTP server. Or, you can use a pre-existing NTP server that is reachable from the management network. You will also need to configure the undercloud and overcloud systems as NTP clients pointing to the NTP server you have chosen to use during the installation process.
For information on installing NTP on the seed cloud host, see Installing an NTP Server.

section.title: Configure proxy information
section.p: Before you begin your installation on the seed cloud host, if necessary configure the proxy information for your environment using the following steps:

li.p: Launch a terminal and log in to your seed cloud host as root:
Edit the /etc/environment file to add the following lines:

codeblock.codeph: export http_proxy=http://<web_proxy_IP>/ export https_proxy=http://<web_proxy_IP>/ export no_proxy=localhost,127.0.0.1,<your 10.x IP address>,<provider_network>
web_proxy_IP is your web proxy IP address. provider_network is your ESX management network

li.p: Log out and re-login to the seed cloud host to activate the proxy configuration.

section.title: Editing the JSON Environment Variables File for Installation
section.p: To make the HPE Helion OpenStack installation process easier, you can enter all of the environment variables required by the installer into a JSON file that will be executed automatically. A JSON file is included in the installation package that you can modify with your environment variables.
For information, see Editing the JSON Environment Variables File for Installation.

section.title: Prepare baremetal.csv file
section.p: Before installing, ensure you have created the baremetal.csv file that is required for installation.

The baremetal.csv file informs the installer of the size of each server that each node will be installed into. In this file you can also specify the role (or node type) for each server so you use the right hardware for different tasks such as storage or compute.
For more information, see Creating the baremetal.csv file.

section.title: Set a default DNS name server
section.p: To set a default DNS name server for your HPE Helion OpenStack Commercial cloud, refer to Enabling Name Resolution from Tenant VMs in the Overcloud before installation.

section.title: Integrating LDAP (Lightweight Directory Access Protocol)
section.p: OPTIONAL The HPE Helion OpenStack Identity service can use Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP) to integrate your organization's existing directory service and user account management processes. LDAP intergration must be performed during the HPE Helion OpenStack installation process.
For information on integrating LDAP, see HPE Helion OpenStack Integrating LDAP.

section.title: Disabling SR-IOV
section.p: In the HPE Helion OpenStack 1.1 release, there is a performance issue with hardware that is configured to support Single Root I/O Virtualization (SR-IOV) on undercloud nodes.

The problem appears as overcloud performance delays for certain operations, like attempting to SSH into a compute node. The problem is related to DNS performance. The DNS service for the overcloud is the dnsmasq process. Occasionally the openvswitch on the undercloud drops packets which are destined for the dnsmasq tap device. The reason the openvswitch occasionally has problems is due to it seeing the tap device MAC address as a source MAC address on eth0. This source MAC address can flap between the tap device and eth0. Properly, the source address should only be the tap device. Because SR-IOV is enabled, a broadcast from the tap device MAC address as source is being sent back by the NIC through eth0. To fix this problem, HPE recommends that you disable SR-IOV in the NIC BIOS (not just in the kernel) on undercloud nodes.

section.title: Understandng Cinder driver support
section.p: Helion OpenStack does not support the Cinder driver LVM., However, LVM is the default if you do not configure VSA or 3 PAR during installation. To address this limitation, HPE recommends that you deploy Helion OpenStack with either 3PAR or VSA.
